TextRepresentation.writtenText: In this zone some cross contamination from the Hot Zone is to be expected. The level of PPE will need to be determined on the basis of dynamic risk assessment.
That portion of the river which is closer to the river's source than the reference point
Supplementary cordon around the outer cordon to control internal traffic access for emergency and other vehicles.
Incident in relation to which the police have not had prior warning or notification to develop strategies, tactics and contingency plans (in contrast to pre-planned incident).
Evacuation of up to 1,000 people from a place of danger to a place of relative safety.
The tactical tier of command and control within a single agency (below Gold level and above Bronze level) at which the response to an emergency is managed.
Lowest level of emergency (Level 1), requiring central government support through a nominated lead government department. See also catastrophic emergency (Level 3); serious emergency (Level 2).
Second highest level of emergency (Level 2), requiring central government direction. See also catastrophic emergency (Level 3); significant emergency (Level 1).
Controlled point through which essential personnel may gain access through the inner cordon.

Decisions and actions taken in accordance with the strategic, tactical and operational objectives defined by emergency responders. At a high level these will be to protect life, contain and mitigate the impacts of the emergency and create the conditions for a return to normality.
Organisation required to plan and prepare a response to an emergency
Point to which all resources arriving at the outer cordon are directed for logging, briefing, equipment issue and deployment.
One of the designated receiving hospitals identified by the strategic health authority and selected by the ambulance service to receive casualties during an emergency.
Location providing access to information for members of the public during an emergency
Local organisation within the National Health service responsible for the first point of consultation for all patients seeking healthcare.

Cordon established around the vicinity of an incident, and encompassing the inner cordon, to control access to a wider area around the scene, to allow the emergency services and other agencies to work unhindered and in privacy.
Private organisation dedicated to pro-social activities such as the relief of suffering and poverty, protection of the environment and community development
National health service 24-hour helpline providing advice and information relating to health in England and Wales (as NHS Direct Wales)
Secure web based infrastructure to enable multi-agency information sharing and which has a specific information function during emergency response and recovery.

An agreement between Category 1 and 2 responders and other organisations not covered by the Act, within the same sector or across sectors and across boundaries, to provide assistance with additional resource during an emergency.
Evacuation of between 1,000 to 25,000 people from a place of danger to a place of relative safety
Protocol to oversee the flow of public information, respond to media queries, handle requests for media interviews, brief the media, and establish a Media Centre
Area adjacent to the scene, staffed by Media Liaison Officers, for the reception and accreditation of media personnel and for briefing on reporting, filming and photographing
Representative who has responsibility for liaising with the media on behalf of his/her organisation
Press and electronic news reporting agencies
Evacuation of a large number of people (100,000+) from a place of danger to a place of relative safety
Generic term for an area to which resources and personnel not immediately required at the scene or being held for further use can be directed to stand by
Event or situation requiring a response under one or more of the emergency services' major incident plans
Accident of a sufficiently large scale to constitute an emergency
Emergency with local impact, the response to which is conducted by local responders, where necessary in conjunction with local government

Cabinet Office (2010) Central Government Arrangements for Responding to an Emergency defines three levels of emergency of national significance. These are, in descending order of magnitude, catastrophic emergency (Level 3); serious emergency (Level 2); significant emergency (Level 1). Below the national level there is a further category, local emergency, the response to which is conducted by local responders, where necessary in conjunction with local government.
A Category 1 responder charged with carrying out a duty under the Act on behalf of a number of responder organisations, so as to co-ordinate its delivery and to avoid unnecessary duplication.
Evacuation of between 25,000 and 100,000 people from a place of danger to a place of relative safety.
Cordon established to secure the immediate scene and provide a measure of protection for personnel working within the area

Event or situation that requires a response from the emergency services or other responders,Note: emergency (or major incident) refers to a specific type of incident requiring special deployment by one or more category 1 responder
Zone of the highest level of contamination.
(Local authority guidance term for) Local authority in whose operational area an emergency has occurred, and which requires support to deal with it
Generic term for an area to which resources and personnel not immediately required at the scene or being held for further use, can be directed to standby
Telephone (and often email) system by which people affected by an emergency can obtain help or services or provide information

The strategic level of command and control (above Silver level and Bronze level) at which policy, strategy and the overall response framework are established and managed for individual responder agencies.
Area, usually within the inner cordon, to which access is normally denied to all personnel, including emergency services. See also cordon.
Building or area on the periphery of an area affected by an emergency, to which evacuees are directed to await transfer to a survivor reception centre or rest centre
An event or situation which threatens serious damage to human welfare in a place in the UK, the environment of a place in the UK, or the security of the UK or of a place in the UK.
That portion of the river which is farther from the river's source than the reference point.

Emergency (usually but not exclusively of natural causes) causing, or threatening to cause, widespread and serious disruption to community life through death, injury, and/or damage to property and/or the environment.
Hospital designated by a Strategic Health Authority as suitable for receiving injured persons from an emergency.
The position on the inner cordon at which decontamination is carried out.
Charitable organisation offering bereavement counselling, advice and support throughout the UK.
Incident in which the police response is likely to have a significant impact on the confidence of the victim, his/her family and/or the community.
Specific definition - emergency of magnitude and/or severity requiring the activation of central government response
Area contained by an outer cordon.
Operations centre from which the management and co-ordination of the response by each emergency service to an emergency are carried out.
Established procedure(s) delineating lines of command and responsibility in the response to an incident or emergency.
Level of command and control of a specific situation
The exercise of vested authority through means of communications and the management of available assets and capabilities, in order to achieve defined objectives.
This is the area beyond the inner cordon.

A person or body listed in Part 3 of Schedule 1 to the Civil Contingencies Act. These are co-operating responders who are less likely to be involved in the heart of multi-agency planning work, but will be heavily involved in preparing for incidents affecting their sectors. The Act requires them to co-operate and share information with other Category 1 and 2 responders.

A person or body listed in Part 1 of Schedule 1 to the Civil Contingencies Act. These bodies are likely to be at the core of the response to most emergencies. As such, they are subject to the full range of civil protection duties in the Act.
An emergency which has an exceptionally high and potentially widespread impact and requires immediate central government direction and support.
Element within the Casualty Bureau responsible for the recording of casualty data forwarded by Hospital Documentation Teams
Ambulance officer who, in liaison with the Medical Incident Commander, ensures an efficient patient throughput at the Casualty Clearing Station.
Initial point of contact and information, maintained by the police, for all data relating to casualties.
(In a maritime emergency) Vessel in distress.
(For Casualty Bureau purpose) Person known, or believed, to be involved in an incident, including evacuees, survivors, and deceased.
A demonstrable ability to respond to and recover from a particular threat or hazard.

The tier of command and control within a single agency (below gold level and silver level) at which the management of hands-on work is undertaken at the incident site(s) or associated areas,Bronze level is also known as the operational level.
Area in which family members may view the bodies of people who have died in an emergency.
See Holding and audit area for deceased people and human remains.
A dedicate route for emergency vehicles to access to and egress from the scene of an emergency or major incident.
Military or emergency services contingent providing additional support in an operation.

Any facility (whether physical or virtual) set up during response to and recovery from an emergency to provide a range of assistance to different categories of people affected by the emergency. See also: Family and Friends Reception Centre; Friends and Relatives Reception Centre; Humanitarian Assistance Centre; Public Information Point; Responders Welfare Centre; Rest Centre; Survivor Reception Centre
The common, secure digital radio system used by the emergency services and others in the resilience and security community. The system is based on the TETRA standards set.

Aircraft (usually a helicopter) used primarily to transport medical or paramedical staff to the site of an incident or emergency and casualties to specialist trauma centres and/or designated hospitals

A voluntary sector organisation that provides 4x4 vehicles and drivers to support emergency responders and voluntary organisations when road or weather conditions prevent their normal vehicles from operating, or their vehicles or drivers are depleted.
Controlled point through which essential non- emergency service personnel may gain access through the outer cor- don.
